column4: NYSE-owner ICE's first-quarter profit drops
column5: April 28 (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange, owner of the New York Stock Exchange, reported a marginal drop in first-quarter profit on Thursday, as higher spending on compensation and benefits outweighed gains from a boost in trading volumes sparked by the COVID-19 pandemic.
column6: Net income attributable to the company was down 0.6% at $646 million, or $1.14 per share, for the three months ended March 31, from $650 million, or $1.17 per share, a year earlier.

column4: Intercontinental Exchange approves 24 members ahead of ICE Futures Abu Dhabi launch
column5: LONDON, March 25 (Reuters) - The Intercontinental Exchange has approved 24 exchange members, of which 18 will be clearing members for ICE’s new exchange in Abu Dhabi.
column6: ICE plans to launch the new exchange, IFAD, alongside 18 related cash settled derivatives on March 29. The key new derivatives are the Murban futures linked to the Emirati crude oil grade.
column7: The exchange includes major global banks such as Citibank, ABN Amro and BNP Paribas.

column4: Exchange leaders say GameStop saga highlights regulatory challenges
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) - The recent trading frenzy around GameStop Corp and other so-called “meme” stocks highlights shortcomings and challenges in the U.S. markets as retail investors become a bigger presence, exchange leaders said on Tuesday.
column6: “The regulatory structure of the U.S. equity markets, in my mind, is flawed,” Jeff Sprecher, chief executive of New York Stock Exchange owner Intercontinental Exchange Inc, said on a panel at the Future Industry Association’s virtual FIA Boca conference.
column7: Regulators have focused on competition between market intermediaries, like brokers and exchanges, rather than between buyers and sellers seeking to get the best prices, and the GameStop event exposed issues with that structure, he said.
column8: In January, retail investors coordinated through social media forums in an attempt to punish hedge funds by buying shares of GameStop and other heavily shorted names, driving up their prices and forcing short sellers to close out positions at big losses.
column9: At the height of the trading mania, several retail brokers restricted the buying of GameStop after collateral requirements needed to clear the trades spiked, angering many traders.
column10: The saga has sparked congressional hearings, regulatory probes and put short selling under scrutiny.
column11: “I’m hoping that in the future regulators will roll back some of the punitive rules and allow the market itself to deal with the intermediary structure,” Sprecher said.
column12: The challenge now is to determine what constitutes unacceptable trading behavior as retail traders coordinate online, said Singapore Exchange CEO Loh Boon Chye.
column13: Market manipulation, when it comes to retail investors’ online activity, has not been defined, which is “concerning,” said CME Group CEO Terry Duffy.
column14: He pointed to the legalization of gambling and marijuana in most U.S. states as examples of regulators taking a more hands-off approach.
column15: “People want to be in charge of their own destiny,” he said.

column4: NYSE-owner Intercontinental Exchange says CFO Scott Hill to retire in May
column5: (Reuters) - New York Stock Exchange-owner Intercontinental Exchange Inc said on Tuesday Chief Financial Officer Scott Hill would retire on May 14 and be replaced by Warren Gardiner, the company’s head of investor relations.
column6: Hill, who was appointed as CFO in 2007, will be with the company as an adviser through February 2023, ICE said.
column7: Before joining ICE, Hill had worked at IBM Corp for 16 years.
column8: Gardiner will take up his new role as CFO after the annual shareholders’ meeting, the company said.

column4: NYSE-owner ICE CFO to retire in May
column5: New York Stock Exchange-owner Intercontinental Exchange Inc (ICE.N) said on Tuesday Chief Financial Officer Scott Hill would retire on May 14 and be replaced by Warren Gardiner, the company's head of investor relations.
column6: Hill, who was appointed as CFO in 2007, will be with the company as an adviser through February 2023, ICE said.
column7: Before joining ICE, Hill had worked at IBM Corp (IBM.N) for 16 years.
column8: Gardiner will take up his new role as CFO after the annual shareholders' meeting, the company said.

column4: NYSE-owner ICE posts rise in fourth-quarter profit
column5: Feb 4 (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange, owner of the New York Stock Exchange, reported a 17% rise in fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, helped by a surge in trading volumes as volatility remained high due to pandemic-related uncertainties.
column6: Net income attributable to the company rose to $526 million, or 93 cents per share, for the quarter ended Dec. 31, from $448 million, or 80 cents per share, a year earlier. (Reporting by Niket Nishant in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: ICE exchange to host UK emissions auctions from next year
column5: Dec 17 (Reuters) - Britain has appointed the Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) to host emissions auctions once the UK’s trading scheme begins next month, the exchange operator said on Thursday.
column6: On Monday, the British government announced its plans for a domestic emissions trading scheme (UK ETS) to replace its participation in the European scheme from Jan. 1, after the country formally leaves the European Union.
column7: “ICE plans to commence auctions and launch the related futures contracts as soon as feasible and no later than the second quarter of 2021, subject to regulatory approval,” ICE said.
column8: Further details on the auction calendar and the spot and futures contracts ICE plans to launch will be announced in due course, it added.
column9: ICE has conducted auctions of British emission allowances under the EU ETS scheme since 2012.

column4: NYSE-owner ICE third-quarter profit beats, helped by mortgage tech deal
column5: (Reuters) - New York Stock Exchange owner Intercontinental Exchange Inc ICE.N on Thursday reported third-quarter profits that beat expectations, helped by its recent $11 billion acquisition of mortgage technology platform Ellie Mae, and financial data sales.
column6: ICE bought Ellie Mae to strengthen its position in mortgage servicing, having made two other deals in the space in recent years, with a view it would benefit from a push to automate the home financing process. The onset of the global coronavirus pandemic accelerated the sector’s digitization.
column7: “Rates are low, millennials are buying, you’re seeing people purchasing new homes to get more space, to get a pool, transitioning out of cities into suburbs,” ICE President Benjamin Jackson said on a conference call with analysts.
column8: ICE closed the Ellie Mae deal at the beginning of September, but said the business added $75 million of revenue in the quarter to its trading and clearing unit, which overall reported $1.2 billion in revenue, up 24% from a year earlier.
column9: Ellie Mae had been expected to contribute $70 million to ICE’s earnings in the quarter, according to estimates from Jefferies analyst Daniel Fannon.
column10: ICE expects Ellie Mae to contribute $220 million to $235 million in fourth quarter revenue, versus Jefferies’ $210 million estimate, Fannon said in a client note.
column11: Excluding onetime items, ICE earned $1.03 per share, 4 cents above the consensus expectations of analysts, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column12: Financial data revenues rose 6% to $589 million.
column13: ICE’s quarterly net income was down from a year earlier, mainly due to expenses from the Ellie Mae deal, at $390 million, or 71 cents per share, from $529 million, or 94 cents per share, a year earlier.
column15: Overall revenue, minus transaction-based expenses, jumped 6% to $1.41 billion, topping estimates of $1.38 billion.

column4: NYSE-owner ICE reports 26% fall in third-quarter profit
column5: Oct 29 (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc, owner of the New York Stock Exchange, reported a 26% fall in third-quarter profit on Thursday, hurt by higher expenses, mainly related to the company’s acquisition of mortgage tech firm Ellie Mae.
column6: Net income attributable to the company fell to $390 million, or 71 cents per share, for the quarter ended Sept. 30, from $529 million, or 94 cents per share, a year earlier.

column4: ICE says to launch ADNOC's Murban futures in Q1/2021
column5: DUBAI, Oct 12 (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc. said on Monday it plans to launch ICE Futures Abu Dhabi (IFAD) and trading in Murban futures contracts late in the first quarter of 2021.
column6: Last year, Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) said its flagship Murban crude would be traded on a new local exchange, IFAD, which will be co-owned by Abu Dhabi, several oil majors and ICE, which is also home to Brent trading. (Reporting by Rania El Gamal)

column4: NYSE-owner ICE to buy Ellie Mae in $11 billion deal
column5: (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc ICE.N (ICE) said on Thursday it would buy Ellie Mae, a technology platform for the mortgage finance industry, from private equity firm Thoma Bravo in a deal valued at $11 billion.
column6: Strengthening its position in mortgage servicing has been a key focus for the owner of the New York Stock Exchange in recent years.
column7: Jeffrey Sprecher, chairman and chief executive of ICE, said in a statement the transaction represented a “one-of-a-kind opportunity” that would “enhance ICE’s growth strategy in mortgage technology”.
column8: Buying Ellie Mae was expected to be accretive to ICE’s adjusted earnings per share in the first full year of ownership, the statement added.
column9: The transaction is expected to yield a substantial profit for Chicago-based Thoma Bravo, which only completed the $3.7 billion take-private acquisition of Ellie Mae in April 2019.
column10: ICE will fund its Ellie Mae purchase, which is expected to close before the end of 2020, predominantly using cash, with 16% of the value covered by the issuance of new ICE common stock.

column4: NYSE-owner ICE reports higher second-quarter earnings
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc ICE.N, owner of the New York Stock Exchange, on Thursday reported a rise in second-quarter profits, helped by a jump in equities and options volumes as volatility remained high due to the coronavirus pandemic.
column6: Net income attributable to the company rose to $523 million, or 95 cents per diluted share, in the quarter ended June 30, from $472 million, or 84 cents per diluted share, a year earlier.
column7: Excluding one-time items, such as M&A costs, ICE posted a profit of $1.07 per share, 3 cents above the mean estimate of analysts, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column8: ICE, which runs futures and equities exchanges, as well as clearing houses and data services, was helped by a 61% increase in cash equities average daily volume (ADV) and a 44% increase in equity options ADV during the quarter as retail investors helped boost participation in those markets.
column9: Revenue from ICE’s transaction and clearing unit, its biggest business, rose 12% to $710 million, while revenue at its data and listings segment, which publishes indexes, analytics and pricing data, grew 3% to $685 million.
column10: Overall revenue, excluding transaction-based expenses, rose 8% to $1.4 billion.

column4: ICE launches global carbon price tracker
column5: LONDON (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) ICE.N has launched an index to track and benchmark the global price of emitting carbon dioxide, it said on Wednesday.
column6: Charging polluters for each tonne of the greenhouse gas they emit is seen by many governments as a way of spurring investment in low carbon technology and helping countries meet pledges made under the 2015 Paris climate agreement. [nL8N28K4Y5]
column7: The ICE Global Carbon Futures Index is made up of pricing from the world’s three most actively traded carbon markets, ICE said: Europe’s Emissions Trading System, California’s Cap and Trade Program and the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI).
column8: RGGI includes Connecticut, Delaware, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York, Rhode Island, and Vermont.
column9: “This is a first step in producing an accurate, transparent global price for carbon, and one that utilizes a market-based mechanism for the evaluation of that price, as we move toward the longer-term shift to a net-zero carbon economy,” said Lynn Martin, President of ICE Data Services.
column10: The global price will be calculated in U.S. dollars using a volume weighted average price of the three markets.
column11: As of 2019, some 46 nations and over 30 cities, states and regions have a price on carbon emissions via a tax or trading schemes, covering just over 20% annual global greenhouse gas emissions, World Bank data showed.

column4: ICE reverts cotton futures daily price limit to 3 cents/lb
column5: April 2 (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc on Thursday said the daily price limit for all Cotton No. 2 futures will be reverted to 3 cents per pound (300 points) above and below the prior day’s settlement price, effective April 3.
column6: The announcement came a day after the exchange expanded the limit to 4 cents per lb.
column7: ICE cotton futures settled up 1.58 cents, or 3.3%, at 49.99 cents per lb, its biggest one-day percentage gain since Oct. 11, helped by a surge in oil prices. Prices had plunged as much as 5.2% to an 11-year low on Wednesday. (Reporting by Eileen Soreng in Bengaluru Editing by Chris Reese)

column4: BRIEF-Intercontinental Exchange Says CEO Jeffrey Sprecher's FY 2019 Total Compensation Was $14.4 Mln vs $14.5 Mln In FY 2018 - SEC Filing
column5: March 26 (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc:
column6: * INTERCONTINENTAL EXCHANGE INC SAYS CEO JEFFREY SPRECHER’S FY 2019 TOTAL COMPENSATION WAS $14.4 MILLION VERSUS $14.5 MILLION IN FY 2018 - SEC FILING
column7: * INTERCONTINENTAL EXCHANGE INC SAYS FOR 2019 CEO PAY RATIO WAS ABOUT 98:1 Source : (bit.ly/2xoCg30) Further company coverage:

column4: BRIEF-ICE Says A Member Of Trading Floor Community & A NYSE Employee Tested Positive For Covid-19
column5: March 18 (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc:
column6: * INTERCONTINENTAL EXCHANGE INC - HAVE BEEN INFORMED THAT A MEMBER OF TRADING FLOOR COMMUNITY AND A NYSE EMPLOYEE HAVE TESTED POSITIVE FOR COVID-19
column7: * INTERCONTINENTAL EXCHANGE - COVID-19 AFFECTED NYSE EMPLOYEE WAS LAST IN EXCHANGE BUILDING ON MARCH 13 & DID NOT HAVE ACCESS TO TRADING FLOOR
column8: * INTERCONTINENTAL EXCHANGE - TRADING FLOOR INDIVIDUAL WHO TESTED POSITIVE FOR COVID-19 WAS LAST IN EXCHANGE BUILDING ON MARCH 13
column9: * INTERCONTINENTAL EXCHANGE - BOTH INDIVIDUALS WHO TESTED POSITIVE FOR COVID-19 WERE NOT PERMITTED TO ENTER BUILDING THIS WEEK Further company coverage:

column4: Intercontinental Exchange closes a London office after coronavirus case
column5: LONDON, March 12 (Reuters) - The American exchange operator ICE has closed one of its London offices after a confirmed case of coronavirus, the commodity exchange said on Thursday in a statement.
column6: Business units with a presence in the affected building will be supported from other locations and by those working remotely during the office closure, it added.
column7: “We are closing the affected office for the remainder of the week to allow for a full deep cleaning and disinfecting.”

column4: Intercontinental Exchange abandons deal talks with eBay
column5: (Reuters) - New York Stock Exchange owner Intercontinental Exchange Inc (ICE) ICE.N said it had decided to stop exploring deal options with eBay Inc EBAY.O, just hours after its chief executive said he would "love" to speak with the e-commerce company.
column6: ICE’s shares, which fell as much as 6.5% during regular trading on Thursday, were up nearly 3% after the bell, following the news, while eBay’s stock fell nearly 7%.
column7: ICE confirmed on Tuesday it had approached eBay to explore “a range of potential opportunities,” following reports it had mulled a more than $30 billion takeover of the online marketplace, but that eBay was unresponsive.
column8: “I didn’t think it’s particularly shocking and outrageous,” Chief Executive Officer Jeffrey Sprecher told analysts on a post-earnings call.
column9: Analysts had questioned how ICE, which also runs futures exchanges and clearinghouses, and provides financial data, would absorb the e-commerce company.
column10: Sprecher said he first reached out to eBay around 20 years ago when ICE was launching as a place to match buyers and sellers of electric power, and that then-CEO Meg Whitman advised him on building an online marketplace. He said eBay was one of dozens of companies ICE has continued to share ideas with.
column11: In recent years, ICE has made acquisitions that have helped it expand beyond its traditional transactional revenue model, to more stable subscription-based revenues, leveraging data and expanding into areas such as electronic mortgage registrations, rewards points, and a market for purchases in video games.
column12: “We know the lane that creates value for us,” Sprecher said. “And so when we think about, is there a marketplace for airline miles or swords and sickles that are on a video game, we’re not crazy. We didn’t lose our minds. We know what our platform does and we know how to lever it.”
column13: The Atlanta-based company said its fourth-quarter profit fell 27%, mainly due to lower revenue from its transaction and clearing business, as market volatility declined.
column14: Quarterly net income fell to $448 million, or 80 cents per share, from $611 million, or $1.07 per share, a year earlier. Discarding one-time items, like merger and acquisition costs, ICE earned 95 cents per share, meeting analysts’ estimates.

column4: Intercontinental Exchange says it explored deal with eBay
column5: (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc (ICE), the owner of the New York Stock Exchange, said on Tuesday it had approached e-commerce company eBay Inc to explore “a range of potential opportunities”.
column6: The statement came after people familiar with the matter said ICE discussed a potential takeover of eBay. The acquisition would exceed $30 billion and represent a substantial departure from ICE’s focus on financial markets.
column7: The move would call on ICE’s technological expertise in running markets to extract efficiencies from eBay’s marketplace platform, which connects buyers and sellers of goods around the world.
column8: ICE said in its statement that “eBay has not engaged in a meaningful way”, and as a result, it was not in negotiations regarding the sale of all or part of eBay.
column9: The Wall Street Journal, which first reported on the deal discussions, said ICE is not interested in eBay’s classified ad unit, which eBay has been considering selling.
column11: EBay’s board issued a statement on Wednesday morning saying it is “aligned and open to all value-enhancing alternatives.”
column12: EBay’s shares ended trading 8.7% firmer at $37.41 on Tuesday following the news, giving it a market value of $30.4 billion. ICE shares fell 7.5% to $92.59, giving the company a market value of $51.6 billion, as investors fretted a deal could be dilutive for the stock exchange operator.
column13: ICE, which also operates futures exchanges and clearing-houses, has faced pressure from U.S. regulators to freeze or reduce the fees it charges to operate financial markets, spurring it to diversify its business.
column14: ICE’s approach rekindles debate among investors over whether eBay should be moving faster to shed its classifieds business, which advertises products and services for sale off the eBay marketplace.
column15: Earlier on Tuesday, activist shareholder Starboard Value LP once again called on eBay Inc to sell off its classifieds business, arguing the company has not made enough progress to improve shareholder value.
column16: “To achieve the optimal outcome, we believe Classifieds must be separated, and a more comprehensive and aggressive operating plan must be put in place to drive profitable growth in the core Marketplace business,” Starboard said in a letter to eBay’s board.
column17: The San Jose, California-based e-commerce firm said it would “review Starboard’s letter and perspectives.”
column18: EBay has been shifting focus to its advertising and payments businesses amid stiff competition in its marketplace business from Amazon.com Inc and Walmart Inc.
column19: The company faced pressure last year not only from Starboard but also from hedge fund Elliott Management. In a settlement, eBay offered a board seat to Elliott’s Jesse Cohn and to Matt Murphy, president and CEO of Marvell Technology, which was backed by Starboard. EBay also agreed in March to conduct a strategic review of its business, and in November agreed to sell StubHub for $4.05 billion in cash.
column20: The company is expected to provide an update this year on its classifieds business, which Elliott valued at between $8 billion and $12 billion.

column4: Major oil companies agree to become partners in new ADNOC exchange: ICE official
column5: ABU DHABI (Reuters) - Major companies including BP, Total, Inpex, Vitol and Shell have agreed to become partners in a new ADNOC Murban crude exchange, an official from Intercontinental Exchange Inc. (ICE) said on Monday.
column6: PetroChina, Korea’s GS Caltex and Japan’s JXTG have also agreed, the official added.

column4: Major oil companies agree to become partners in new ADNOC exchange -ICE official
column5: ABU DHABI, Nov 11 (Reuters) - Major companies including BP, Total, Inpex, Vitol and Shell have agreed to become partners in a new ADNOC Murban crude exchange, an official from Intercontinental Exchange Inc. (ICE) said on Monday.
column6: PetroChina, Korea’s GS Caltex and Japan’s JXTG have also agreed, the official added. (Reporting by Rania El Gamal; editing by Jason Neely)

column4: NYSE-owner ICE's profit rises nearly 4%
column5: Aug 1 (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc, which owns the New York Stock Exchange, posted a 3.7% rise in quarterly profit on Thursday, helped by growth across both its transaction and clearing business and data services unit.
column6: Net income attributable to the company rose to $472 million, or 84 cents per share, in the second quarter ended June 30 from $455 million, or 78 cents per share, a year earlier. (reut.rs/2YCBUhd)
column7: Total revenue, excluding transaction-based expenses, rose 4% to $1.29 billion. (Reporting by Bharath Manjesh in Bengaluru; Editing by Anil D’Silva)

column4: NYSE-owner ICE reports 4.3 pct rise in profit
column5: May 2 (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc, which owns the New York Stock Exchange, reported a 4.3 percent rise in first-quarter profit on Thursday, helped by growth in its data services unit.
column6: Net income attributable to the company rose reut.rs/2VzHfs8 to $484 million, or 85 cents per share, in the quarter ended March 31, from $464 million, or 79 cents per share, a year earlier.
column7: Total revenue, excluding transaction-based expenses, rose 3.7 percent to $1.27 billion. (Reporting by Bharath Manjesh in Bengaluru; Editing by Arun Koyyur)

column4: NYSE-owner ICE's quarterly profit surges 22 percent
column5: Feb 7 (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc, which owns the New York Stock Exchange, reported a 22 percent rise in fourth-quarter adjusted profit on Thursday, helped by a surge in its transaction and clearing business.
column6: Adjusted net income attributable to the company rose to $536 million, or 94 cents per share, in the quarter ended Dec. 31, from $441 million, or 75 cents per share, a year earlier. (reut.rs/2GerMXg)
column7: Total revenue, excluding transaction-based expenses, rose 14.1 percent to $1.31 billion. (Reporting by Bharath Manjesh in Bengaluru; Editing by James Emmanuel)

column4: NYSE-owner ICE's profit rises 23.5 pct
column5: Oct 31 (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc, the owner of the New York Stock Exchange, reported a 23.5 percent rise in quarterly profit on Wednesday, helped by a boost in its transaction and clearing business and market data services.
column6: Net income attributable to the company rose to $458 million, or 79 cents per share, in the third quarter ended Sept. 30, from $371 million, or 63 cents per share, a year earlier. (reut.rs/2Pz9JyY)
column7: Total revenue, excluding transaction-based expenses, rose 4.7 percent to $1.2 billion.
column8: Excluding one-time items, the company earned 85 cents per share. (Reporting by Bharath Manjesh in Bengaluru)

column4: ICE's new Houston crude futures contract begins trading
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) - Intercontinental Exchange Inc said its new Permian West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil futures contract deliverable in Houston, Texas, will begin trading on Monday.
column6: The trade month will be December and the contract will be deliverable at Magellan Midstream Partners LP’s East Houston terminal, ICE said in a statement.
column7: On Monday, ICE will list 36 months of flat-price Permian WTI contracts and calendar spreads, as well as inter-commodity spreads for the Houston contract versus Brent and the Houston contract versus WTI.
column8: The primary U.S. futures contract is delivered at the storage hub in Cushing, Oklahoma, as has been the case since the contract was started in the early 1980s.
column9: However, U.S. crude exports have surged after Washington lifted a decades-long ban, making Gulf Coast markets liquid and the sought-after destination for producers to send their barrels.
column10: “Houston has become the pricing center for U.S. crude oil production and exports, and the new Permian WTI futures contract is designed to serve hedging and trading opportunities in this growing market,” ICE said in a statement.
column11: The company first announced the contract in July, following which rival CME Group Inc said in September it would offer a new WTI Houston crude futures contract with three physical delivery locations on the Enterprise Products Partners LP’s Houston system, beginning in the fourth quarter.

column6: * INTERCONTINENTAL EXCHANGE REPORTS RECORD FIRST QUARTER 2018 REVENUES OF $1.2 BILLION, +5% Y/Y AND GAAP DILUTED EPS OF $0.79; RECORD ADJUSTED DILUTED EPS OF $0.90, +22% Y/Y

column4: ICE tweaks raw sugar contract rules around CAFTA quota -notice
column5: NEW YORK, April 17 (Reuters) - The Intercontinental Exchange Inc on Tuesday said it had amended rules for delivery of raw sugar to the No 11 futures contract to ensure that Central American sweetener cannot be shipped to the United States through a preferential quota.
column6: Sugar from Central America and the Dominican Republic can enter the highly-protected U.S. market at a lower tariff-rate under a U.S.-Central American Free trade agreement (CAFTA). Traders often purchase physical deliveries through the ICE Futures U.S. contract. That sugar can come from one of 29 origins, according to the exchange website.
column7: The amendment ensures that sugar delivered against the No 11 contract from any of those origins cannot be sent into the United States under the CAFTA quota, ICE said in a notice published on Tuesday.
column8: The rules of delivery against the No 11 previously had a similar rule that applied to any similar preferential agreements for sugar into the European Union.
column9: The change is effective with the March 2019 expiry, the notice said. (Reporting by Chris Prentice Editing by Tom Brown)
